repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Patricia Miller Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority collection
did.physloc: Series 1 and 2 are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Series 3 is located on-site. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract: The Patricia Miller Washington Metropolitican Area Transit Authority collection largely consists of photographs and maps documenting the the construction of the Metrorail system between the years of 1950 and 2000. The collection also includes WMATA publications, including flyers and newsletters, that provide updates on the progress of the construction of the Metrorail system.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into 3 series: Publications, Photographs, and Maps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains publications and maps of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, photographs of the progression of the construction of the rail system, and oversized photographs mounted on foam core. The materials date from 1950-2000.

bioghist.head: Historical
bioghist.p: The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, WMATA, with central offices in Washington, DC, is the private agency charged with the coordination and operation of mass transit in the National Capital Region. This area includes Montgomery and Prince George's Counties in Maryland, Arlington, the District of Columbia, and Fairfax County in Virginia.

The Interim Board of Directors of WMATA first met in mid-October, 1966, chaired by Brig. Gen. Jackson Graham, formerly Engineering Commissioner for the District. WMATA was formally established on February 20, 1967. WMATA formally received its charter in September 1967.

WMATA superseded the National Capital Transportation Agency (NCTA); a federal agency established by President Eisenhower in 1960 and inherited the bus and rail plans of the NCTA. For bus operations, WMATA bought out the routes from the private bus companies operating within its purview (with the exception of Montgomery County's "Ride-On" system) and established a single operation, Metrobus, to serve in their place.

For the creation of Metrorail, popularly known as "the Metro," routes, designs, and plans were finalized by the late 1960s. Work on the subway component began immediately upon the creation of WMATA. DeLeuw, Cather were retained as chief engineering consultants. The firm of Harry Weese and Associates were named chief architectural consultants. Weese was sent on a worldwide tour of subway systems, in order to draw inspiration and ideas for possible station architecture. The final design, agreed upon by a special committee that included the District of Columbia Board of Fine Arts and several artists and architects, was proposed in 1968.

First ground was broken for the subway above the future Judiciary Square station on December 9, 1969. The Metro ran its first day of revenue service, on the abbreviated Red Line beginning at Dupont Circle, in June 1976. Public response was enthusiastic. The system was a highlight of the Bicentennial celebrations one month later, during which it transported thousands of visitors.

bioghist.head: Biographical
bioghist.p: Patrcia Miller first joined Bechtel, the engineering consultant to Metro, as a Senior Draftsman in 1974. Her work involved the installation of the various appurtenances which made the system work. These consisted of millions of dollars worth of contracts to oversee the installation of graphics, kiosks, traction power, automatic train control, fare collection, and track work.

In late 1983, WMATA decided that they could handle the engineering themselves. Miller opted to leave Bechtel and obtain employment with WMATA in 1984 as an Assistant Office Engineer. She stayed on with WMATA until her retirement as an Office Engineer in May of 2004.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Two published maps have been separated from this series and cataloged. The maps are titled Washington, D.C., Transportation Map (1988) and Washington D.C. and Metropolitan Area (1976). These maps have been cataloged as part of the Special Collections stacks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include multiple different publications produced by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority, including Capsule History of WMATA, Metro Ride Guide, Metro Memo Tabloid, Intercom, Inside Metro, Metropolitan Times, and Metro Weekly.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by the name of the publication and chronologically within each publication.

did.unittitle: Official Program Arlington Orange Line Celebration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series predominantly consist of photographs that document the construction of the Metrorail system. Materials include both color and black and white photographs in various sizes.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Prince George's Plaza, Shaw, Wheaton, Van Ness, Woodley Park, Cleveland Park, Pentagon City, Greenbelt, Dunn-Loring-Merrifield, and College Park.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Greenbelt, U Street, Federal Triangle, Wheaton, Cleveland Park, Pentagon City, Prince George's Plaza, New Carrollton, Federal Center, and Foggy Bottom.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Federal Triangle, Prince George's Plaza, U Street, Foggy Bottom, Twinbrook, West Hyattsville, Greenbelt, Dunn-Loring, West Falls Church, Vienna, Takoma Park, Shaw, Rockville, and Medical Center.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: College Park, Wheaton, Shaw, Anacostia, Foggy Bottom, Farragut West, Crystal City, Federal Triangle, Reagan Airport, and L'Enfant Plaza.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Federal Triangle, Pentagon City, West Hyattsville, College Park, Prince George's Plaza, Huntington, Potomac, L'Enfant Plaza, and Twinbrook.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Tenleytown, Friendship Heights, Federal Triangle, Stadium-Armory, Federal Center, Mt. Vernon, UDC, Wheaton, West Hyattsville, Prince George's Plaza, Greenbelt, Dunn-Loring, West Falls Church, and East Falls Church.

odd.p: Reagan, Vienna, Dunn-Loring, West Hyattsville, Anacostia, Prince George's Plaza, College Park, Greenbelt, Shady Grove, Rockville, and Medical Center.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Shady Grove, Rockville, White Flint, Grosvenor, Prince George's Plaza, College Park, Metro Center, Wheaton, and Friendship Heights.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Cleveland Park, Van Ness/UDC, Rosslyn, L'Enfant Plaza, and Van Dorn.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Federal Triangle, New Carrollton, Potomac, Van Ness/UDC, and Foggy Bottom.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Foggy Bottom, Van Ness/UDC, Friendship Heights, Tenleytown, Pentagon City, L'Enfant Plaza, and Federal Center.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: L'Enfant Plaza, Pentagon City, Prince George's Plaza, Greenbelt, Foggy Bottom, U Street, and New Carrollton.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Prince George's Plaza, U Street, Friendship Heights, Tenleytown, Foggy Bottom, Pentagon City, Van Ness/UDC, West Hyattsville, and Navy Yard.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Navy Yard, New Carrollton, Prince George's Plaza, Foggy Bottom, Pentagon City, U Street, Anacostia, Cleveland Park, and Van Ness/UDC.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Federal Triangle, L'Enfant Plaza, Navy Yard, Van Dorn, West Hyattsville, Cleveland Park, Van Ness/UDC, Friendship Heights, Woodley Park-Zoo/Adams Morgan, West Falls Church, Fort Totten, Shaw, College Park, Pentagon City, and Tenleytown.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Shaw, U Street, Pentagon City, West Falls Church, Fort Totten, Anacostia, Foggy Bottom, College Park, and L'Enfant Plaza.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Greenbelt, Dunn Loring, Federal Center, Federal Triangle, Friendship Heights, Tenleytown, and Navy Yard.

odd.head: This folder contains photographs of the construction of the following Metrorail stations:
odd.p: Navy Yard, Wheaton, Minnesota Avenue, L'Enfant Plaza, and West Hyattsville.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains maps of both the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit authority metro rail system, as well the Washington Metropolitan area in general.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Two published maps have been separated from this series and cataloged. The maps are titled Washington, D.C., Transportation Map (1988) and Washington D.C. and Metropolitan Area (1976). These maps have been cataloged as part of the Special Collections stacks.
